subject: chemistry
title: Activity Series of Metals MCQ Problems

problems.question: Which of the following reactions is possible?
problems.hint: Check the reactivity series: more reactive metals displace less reactive ones from compounds.
problems.detailed: Sodium is above magnesium in the reactivity series, so \(\ce{Na}\) can displace \(\ce{Mg}\) from \(\ce{MgSO4}\). Other reactions are not possible because the single metal is less reactive than the one in the compound.
problems.author: Alexia 'Jujen' Butu

problems.question: A piece of \(\ce{Zn}\) is placed in a solution of \(\ce{CuSO4}\). The statement that describes what happens is:
options: The reaction occurs because Zn is more reactive than Cu
The reaction does not occur because the metals are equally reactive
The reaction does not occur because Zn is less reactive than Cu
The reaction occurs only upon strong heating
problems.hint: Compare Zn and Cu on the reactivity series.
problems.detailed: Since zinc is above copper in the activity series, it displaces copper from its salt: \(\ce{Zn + CuSO4 -> ZnSO4 + Cu}\).
problems.author: Alexia 'Jujen' Butu

problems.question: Which of these reactions is wrong?
problems.hint: Check whether the free metal is more reactive than the metal in the salt.
problems.detailed: Copper is less reactive than magnesium, so it cannot displace magnesium from \(\ce{MgCl2}\). Therefore (A) is the incorrect reaction.
problems.author: Alexia 'Jujen' Butu

problems.question: A chemist analyzed a sample of 3 unknown metals. The results: X displaces Y\(^{2+}\), Y displaces Z\(^{2+}\), but X cannot displace Mg\(^{2+}\). What is the correct order of electropositivity?
problems.hint: Stronger displacers are higher in the activity series.
problems.detailed: Since X > Y > Z in reactivity, but Mg is above X, the order is Mg > X > Y > Z.
problems.author: Alexia 'Jujen' Butu

problems.question: A Fe plate (5.6 g) and a Cu plate (6.4 g) are placed in heated \(\ce{H2SO4}\). The correct statement is:
problems.hint: Consider which metal reacts with acids under heating.
problems.detailed: Copper does not react with acids under normal conditions, but Fe does: \(\ce{Fe + H2SO4 -> FeSO4 + H2}\). Moles Fe = 5.6/56 = 0.1. Mass of FeSO4 = 0.1 × 160 = 16 g.
problems.author: Alexia 'Jujen' Butu

problems.question: An equimolar mixture of \(\ce{Fe}\), \(\ce{Cu}\) and \(\ce{Al}\) has a mass of 14.7 g. A solution of \(\ce{HCl}\) is added. What is the volume of \(\ce{H2}\) released at STP?
problems.hint: Only \(\ce{Fe}\) and \(\ce{Al}\) react with HCl, not Cu. Use moles, stoichiometry, and gas laws.
problems.detailed: 1 mol Fe (56 g), 1 mol Cu (63.5 g), 1 mol Al (27 g). Total = 146.5 g for 1 mol each. For 14.7 g, divide by 146.5 ≈ 0.1 mol each. Reaction: \(\ce{2Al + 6HCl -> 2AlCl3 + 3H2}\), \(\ce{Fe + 2HCl -> FeCl2 + H2}\). Moles \(\ce{H2}\) = 0.1 (Fe) + 0.15 (Al) = 0.25 mol. Volume = 0.25 × 22.4 = 5.6 L.
problems.author: Alexia 'Jujen' Butu

problems.question: A piece of \(\ce{Zn}\) is placed in 100 mL \(\ce{FeSO4}\) solution of 0.15 M (consider yield 100%). What’s the mass of the Zn piece that reacts?
problems.hint: Use \(\ce{Zn + FeSO4 -> ZnSO4 + Fe}\). Calculate moles of \(\ce{FeSO4}\) from volume and molarity, then relate to moles of Zn.
problems.detailed: Moles of \(\ce{FeSO4}\) = 0.1 L × 0.15 M = 0.015 mol. Stoichiometry is 1:1, so \(n_{Zn} = 0.015\). Mass of Zn = \(0.015 × 65 = 0.975 g\).
problems.author: Alexia 'Jujen' Butu

problems.question: An unknown mass of aluminium is placed in a \(\ce{HCl}\) solution. The mass of hydrogen released is 3 g. Consider the yield 80%. What’s the mass of aluminium?
problems.hint: Use the balanced equation \(\ce{2Al + 6HCl -> 2AlCl3 + 3H2}\). Relate molar masses to hydrogen mass and adjust for yield.
problems.detailed: Moles of \(\ce{H2}\): \(3/2 = 1.5\) mol. At 100% yield, this would require \(2/3 \times 1.5 = 1.0\) mol \(\ce{Al}\). Mass of Al = 27 g. Since yield is 80%, actual mass = \(27/0.8 = 33.75\, g\).
problems.author: Alexia 'Jujen' Butu

problems.question: An Aluminum wire (6.7 g) is placed in \(\ce{Cu(NO3)2}\). After some time, its mass is 20.5 g. What is the mass of copper deposited?
problems.hint: Set up a mass balance: final mass = remaining Al + deposited Cu.
problems.detailed:
Reaction: \(\ce{2Al + 3Cu^{2+} -> 2Al^{3+} + 3Cu}\). Thus, 1 mol Al deposits 1.5 mol Cu.
Mass balance: \(m_{final} = m_{Al,0} - x \times M_{Al} + 1.5x \times M_{Cu}\).
Substitute: \(20.50 = 6.70 - 26.98x + 1.5(63.55)x\).
\(x = 13.80 / 68.34 \approx 0.202\ mol\).
Mass of Cu = \(1.5 \times 0.202 \times 63.55 \approx 19.3\ g\).
problems.author: Alexia 'Jujen' Butu
